Welcome to sanskrit_data’s documentation!¶

Indices and tables¶

  • Index
  • Module Index
  • Search Page

sanskrit_data.schema¶

schema package contains modules which define various modules describing various classes for storing Sanskrit data, and their corresponding JSON schema.

  • At the base of every such class is the common.JsonObject class.
  • Just pick the most suitable class to store your data (or contribute it here).

classmethod get_jsonpickle_typeid()[source]¶
classmethod get_wire_typeid()[source]¶
classmethod make_from_dict(input_dict)[source]¶

Defines our canonical way of constructing a JSON object from a dict.

All other deserialization methods should use this. Note that this assumes that json_class_index is populated properly! from sanskrit_data.schema import * before using this should take care of it. :param input_dict: :return:

to_json_map()[source]¶

One convenient way of ‘serializing’ the object.

So, the type must be properly set. Many functions accept such json maps, just as they accept strings.

update_collection(db_interface)[source]¶
validate(db_interface=None)[source]¶
Parameters:db_interface – Potentially useful in subclasses to perfrom validations (eg. is the target_id valid).

This value may not be availabe: for example when called from the from_details methods. :return:

It is an array only for consistency. For any given BookPortion, one can get the right order of contained BookPortions by seeking all BookPortions referring to it in the targets list, and sorting them by their target position values.', 'maxLength': 1}, 'jsonClass': {'enum': ['BookPortion'], 'type': 'string'}}, 'description': 'A BookPortion could represent a Book or a chapter or a verse or a half-verse or a sentence or any such unit.'}¶

sanskrit_data.db¶

This package aims to achieve database neutrality - we abstract database-client operations and database operations using interfaces so as to enable one to easily switch the database one uses.
